Posts.Content: Apr 26, 2008 04:49AM Dukemom2 wrote: DionM, You came to the right place.  The people here are amazingly supportive, and I've found it a great comfort to read the posts and gather the strength and encouragement of the women here. Ramble away to us anytime!  Come here to ask questions, vent, and share your worries and concerns.  I am bypassing the stereotactic biopsy (turns out it wasn't even an option for me, as my boobs are too small) and I will be having 3 excisional biopsies week after next.  However, from what I've read from those who have had the stereotactic biopsy, you will be sore for a few days.  They say wearing an athletic bra day and night helps a great deal.  Even though my kids are now adults, I haven't told them about this yet either.  I'm waiting until I know what (if anything) I'm dealing with.  With any luck, I will be able to tell them that I had a couple of biopsies and everything was benign.  I have a family history of bc too:  my maternal grandmother died of metastatic bc, as did one of my mother's first cousins (who I just learned tested positive for the bc gene).  Even though I know the odds are in my favor (80% of biopsies are benign!!), like most of us, my mind can't stop itself from imagining the worst. I know you are scared, and I know the waiting is horrendous.  You will get through this. As difficult as it is, try to take it one day at a time, and one step at a time.  When the anxiety gets too high, try some slow, controlled deep breathing.  Keep repeating to yourself that you can and will get through this.  Find something to distract yourself.  For some, doing fun things (movies, shopping) helps.  I read of one woman who said she had the cleanest toilets while she was waiting for her results.  I'm still at the stage of waiting for the biopsies to be done, but I've found that sorting and organizing old paperwork is a great diversion for me.  At the moment, I'm working on getting through bank records for my husband and I and our kids from a few years ago.  It's tedious and a perfect distraction for me. Hang in there Dion.  We all know exactly how you feel.  You aren't alone.  Please keep posting to let us know how you are doing, and be sure to tell us as soon as you have your report.  I'm sending calming and benign thoughts your way! Dukemom

Posts.Content: May 28, 2008 05:14PM Dukemom2 wrote: Melinda, According to The American Cancer Society's website, http://www.cancer.org/: "In a fine needle aspiration (FNA) biopsy, the doctor (a pathologist, radiologist, or surgeon) uses a very thin needle attached to a syringe to withdraw (aspirate) a small amount of tissue from a suspicious area. This tissue is then looked at under a microscope. The needle used for FNAB is thinner than the ones used for blood tests. . . A fine needle aspiration biopsy can sometimes miss a cancer if the needle is not placed into the area of cancer cells. If it does not provide a clear diagnosis, or your doctor is still suspicious, a second biopsy or a different type of biopsy should be done." A stereotactic core needle biopsy uses x-ray equipment and a computer to analyze the pictures (x-ray views). The computer then pinpoints exactly where in the abnormal area to place the needle tip. This procedure is often used to biopsy microcalcifications (calcium deposits). " Just for your own information, my radiologist suggested a stereotactic biopsy for me too.  My gyn recommended I have a consultation with a surgeon.  He told me that while he prefers a stereotactic biopsy when possible, because it is less invasive, in my case my breasts are too small.  He said he'd hate to have them try several times, only to tell me that they couldn't get a sample.  Me too!!  I had a wire guided excisional biopsy (times 2) for clusters of microcalcifications.  (My results were benign, but with ADH - atypical ductal hyperplasia.)  I'm from another part of Florida, so I haven't heard of Dr. Masood.  Best of luck to you.  I know this is scary, and it's very stressful.  Please try to remember that 80% of biopsies are benign.  Hang onto that thought, and I hope and pray that your results are in that category, BENIGN! Please keep posting, ask any questions you may have, and vent away anytime.  We all know what you are going through.  Keep us posted! Posts.Content: Jun 7, 2008 10:40AM Dukemom2 wrote: Yes, please do talk to your gyn about your concerns and fears.  (If s/he wasn't the person who ordered the mammo for you, be sure to take a copy of the report with you.)  In the meantime, please try to relax.  I know, easier said than done, but you need to try. When a radiologist reads the films, s/he decides if there is anything of enough concern to warrant a biopsy at this time.  Apparently your radiologist wasn't overly concerned, otherwise s/he would have recommended a biopsy instead of a follow-up in 6 months. The BI-RAD system for mammograms is as follows: Category 0:  Need additional imaging Category 1:  Negative Category 2:  Benign finding Category 3:  Probably benign, short term follow up                                 recommended Category 4:  Suspicious abnormality - biopsy should be                     considered Category 5:  Highly suggestive of malignancy -                     appropriate action should be taken It sounds like your BI-RAD score was a 3.  Many women who have a score of 4 and undergo a biopsy end up with benign results.  Even a score of 5 on a mammogram doesn't mean you have a malignancy.  The ONLY way to tell if something is benign or malignant is to have a biopsy and have a pathologist look at the tissue under a microscope. If this was your first mammogram, the radiologist didn't have anything to compare your films to - which can make it difficult to read.  Plus, given your age, your breast tissue is dense, which can also make it difficult to interpret your films.  Having another mammo in 6 months will allow the radiologist to compare those films against the ones you just had taken.  That, in turn, will allow him/her to see if anything has changed.  Make a list of specific questions you have for your gyn at your appointment Monday.  Keep in mind you do not have a diagnosis of cancer, or even a suggestion that you need a biopsy.  Right now, all you have is a report that says the radiologist wants another set of films in 6 months to see anything has changed. Please keep breathing, and don't get ahead of yourself.  Have fun with your kids this weekend.  Dukemom

Posts.Content: Dec 8, 2008 03:25PM Dukemom2 wrote: Oh Michelle, that stinks - I am so sorry it was that bad.  It's a good thing you went back when you did, and didn't let it fester over the weekend! After my first excisional biopsy, I was very concerned about the scar and doing everything I could to minimize its appearance.  I faithfully applied Kelo-cote gel to it daily (like Mederma).  A month later, the surgeon went back into that incision a second time and I got a new incision in another spot, same breast.  Now I have a stereotactic site (same breast) that only stopped oozing blood after 5 days.  I still have the steri strips on.  I've given up on appearances.  At this point I look at my breast and think I'm lucky it's still there.  Although if things keep up at this rate, as small chested as I am, there won't be much left! Ouch on re-suturing without the benefit of even a local.  Just be glad that they caught the infection before it got any worse.  After you have fully healed, ask your surgeon when you can start applying a scar minimizing cream or gel.  Kelo-cote is more expensive than Mederma, but it works very well: http://www.kelocote.com/ However if you are interested in buying some, it's cheaper here: http://www.makemeheal.com/mmh/product.do?id=10066  Be sure to check with your surgeon before applying anything to the incision.  Especially since your incision was reopened and re-sutured, you will have to wait longer after the stitches are out before you can put something on it.  Hang in there Michelle.  Dukemom

Posts.Content: Apr 6, 2008 10:47AM Dukemom2 wrote: Heartbroken, Here's some information on calcifications from http://www.breastdoc.com/: "Calcifications are small calcium deposits in the breast that can be detected only by mammography (breast x-ray). They are divided into two categories, macrocalcifications and microcalcifications. Macrocalcifications are coarse calcium deposits that most likely represent degenerative changes in the breasts, such as aging of the breast arteries, old injuries, or inflammations. These deposits are associated with benign (noncancerous) conditions and do not require a biopsy (surgery that removes the tissue for examination under a microscope). Macrocalcifications are found in about 50 percent of women over the age of 50, and in about 10 percent of women under the age of 50. Microcalcifications are tiny specks of calcium in the breast. These minute calcifications are usually in an area of rapidly dividing cells. When many microcalcifications are seen in one area, they are referred to as a cluster and they may indicate a small cancer. About half of the cancers detected by mammography appear as a cluster of microcalcifications. An area of microcalcification that is seen on a mammogram does not always mean that cancer is present. In some cases, the microcalcifications do not even indicate a need for a biopsy. Instead, a doctor may advise a follow-up mammogram within 3 to 6 months. In other cases, the microcalcifications are more suspicious and a biopsy is recommended." My routine mammogram a few weeks ago showed a cluster of microcalcifications in the upper outer quadrant of my right breast.  I'm having a cone compression mammogram and an ultrasound tomorrow.  When my gyn told me I'd need to go in for these additional tests, she also told me I'd have to follow up with a surgeon.  So, I'm guessing there is a biopsy in my immediate future too.  Let me know when you are scheduled for your biopsy.  I'll be thinking good thoughts for you! Posts.Content: Nov 6, 2008 03:43PM Dukemom2 wrote: Earlier this year, I had 3 clusters of microcalcifications.  Two were benign, one was ADH - atypical ductal hyperplasia.  ADH is considered one step before DCIS - it's too many abnormal cells, but it isn't yet a malignancy.  My breast are too small for stereotactic biopsies, so I had wire guided excisional biopsies (also known as surgical biopsies or lumpectomies). Having ADH puts one at a higher risk of developing cancer in either breast, so I'm being followed by both my breast surgeon and by an oncologist, in addition to my gyn.  Good luck, here's hoping for benign results for you!

Posts.Content: Nov 3, 2008 12:22PM Dukemom2 wrote: You'll be ok, honest.  The wire insertion isn't bad at all.  I had a couple inserted earlier this year, before my excisional biopsies.  You will first go to radiology.  They will numb your breast (my radiologist put a topical anesthetic on the skin before he injected the local anesthetic into my breast).  With your breast in the mammogram machine (I was sitting in a chair), the radiologist inserts the wire into the area of concern.  It wasn't painful, but it was a little uncomfortable.  For me, it wasn't any more uncomfortable than a regular mammogram.  They cover the wire(s) with gauze, and will wheel you over to pre op.  When you wake up after the surgery, you will be in recovery.  After a little time there, you will go home. If you have any questions, ask away.  Hugs to you as you wait until tomorrow (then more hugs for while you wait for the path report).  Waiting stinks, but we're all right here waiting with you! Dukemom

Posts.Content: Jun 29, 2008 11:14AM Dukemom2 wrote: Jessia, I am so sorry you are having to deal with this.  It is very scary to feel a lump, or to be told that there is an "area of concern" that has shown up on screening.  We all tend to immediately think of the worst possible outcome.  Our silly minds want to wander off to dark places, places they don't need to be going. Many women have lumpy breasts, also described as fibrocystic breasts.  It is very common.  (My gyn told me that palpating my breasts is like feeling a bowl of lumpy oatmeal - lovely analogy!)  Also, cysts are common in younger breasts, and they tend to change with your hormones and cycles.  This is why she wants to check it after your cycle, because it might no longer be there. In any case, you have every right to ask for some type of imaging, to see what is going on.  A mammogram isn't often done on women younger than 50, because your breasts are more dense and it is more difficult to see an abnormality/mass on a mammogram (it's been described as trying to find a polar bear in a snow storm).  Fibroadenomas are also fairly common - they are perfectly benign lumps.  Since many of us here feel that the only good lump is a lump in a jar (i.e. if you have a lump, have it biopsied so you know for sure), I would ask for an ultrasound.  An ultrasound can show the location of a mass, and can also tell if the mass if solid, or if it is filled with liquid (a cyst).  If it is a cyst, they can insert a tiny needle and aspirate (remove) the fluid.  If it is solid, by all means you can request a biopsy.  While it is important to get it checked out, please remember that overall, 80% of all breast biopsies are BENIGN.  Those are wonderful odds.  It's normal that you are very frightened now, but I can tell that you are going to pursue this and put your mind to rest.  Take a few deep breaths, and know that you will be alright.  Come here to ask any questions, to share your fears and anxieties with us, or just to hang out.  We all understand how you feel, and we'll be right here with you. Warm hugs, Dukemem

Posts.Content: Apr 25, 2008 10:05AM Dukemom2 wrote: Marcella: First of all, congratulations on doing self exams!  Radiologists can get a good idea whether a lump is something that needs to be explored further or not, but the only way to know for sure is to biopsy the lump. I know you are freaking out, we all do.  Take a deep breath, and please remember that 80% of breast lumps biopsied are benign. A couple of years ago, my daughter (in her early 20s) discovered a lump in her breast.  She had an ultrasound and was referred to a surgeon.  The surgeon gave her 3 choices:  keep an eye on it, have a repeat ultrasound in 6 months to see if it had changed; have a fine needle biopsy of the lump; or have a lumpectomy.  She wanted the lumpectomy - she wanted it out even if it turned out to be benign.  She had the lumpectomy, it was a fibroadenoma (benign), and she has peace of mind. Everyone here will tell you that the waiting is excruciating. I have learned a great deal from this website, and have found great comfort and support from this community. Try not to get too far ahead of yourself (easier said than done).  Please keep posting, and let us know how you are doing.  You will be in my prayers! Dukemom

Posts.Content: Jun 23, 2008 01:48AM Dukemom2 wrote: mykids, I'm sorry you found a lump and are having to deal with this.  This isn't a chat room, but a message board - so you can take your time when you post here.  It may take a little while for someone to come along and answer you. I'm sorry you had to wait; it can be a little slow here on the weekends. What did your doctor tell you when he/she gave you your ultrasound report?  Has it been suggested that you have the lesions biopsied?  An ultrasound can tell the radiologist whether a mass is solid, or if it is filled with liquid - a cyst.  Cysts are almost always benign, but would likely be aspirated (have the fluid withdrawn with a needle) and have the fluid checked under a microscope. Your ultrasound report says that you have two solid lesions.  I would imagine that you will have them biopsied.  The only way to be certain if a mass is malignant or benign is to biopsy it:  take a tiny piece of tissue and have a pathologist look at it under a microscope.  Many of us here feel the only good lump is a lump in a jar - meaning all lumps should be biopsied and checked.  There are a couple of ways to biopsy a lump, depending on the location of the lump and the size of your breast.  Here's a link with information on biopsies: http://www.imaginis.com/breasthealth/biopsy/biopsy_methods.asp I know this is scary.  Please remember that overall, 80% of all breast biopsies are benign.  The odds are very much in your favor, but it is very smart to get any breast lump checked out.  Feel free to post any and all questions you may have, or to just share your anxieties and fears.  Best of luck to you, and please keep us posted! Dukemom

Posts.Content: Apr 28, 2008 04:58AM Dukemom2 wrote: sissyjane, The odds are that you are indeed worried for nothing.  Even if you do end up having something that the radiologist feels should be biopsied, please remember that 80% of biopsies are benign (such a wonderful word!). I know you are frightened and worried.  We all are when this happens.  These are our bodies, and it's scary. Try to take some slow deep breaths and don't get too far ahead of yourself.  I was called back from my normal annual mammogram (in March) for diagnostic mammos to check out a suspicious area.  The radiologist read the first set of diagnostic films and found two other areas, so I had another set of films taken while I was still there.  I was told before I left that day that I'd need the areas biopsied.  (My biopsies are scheduled for next week.)  The good news is that with the diagnostic mammograms you very often get the results while you are there!  Some women may have a biopsy the same day, but that wasn't my experience.  I was referred to a surgeon, who discussed the various options for biopsies.  It turns out only one option would work for me - the excisional biopsy. The only way to tell for sure that something is benign is to do a biopsy.  The way your report reads, it sounds to me as if the radiologist was saying that the area in question appears to be benign, but since it has grown slightly since you last exam, it warrants a further look.  With the diagnostic mammogram, they get a magnified view of the specific area, so they get more detail and can better evaluate it. It's very normal for you to be worried.  Your husband is going to be concerned too.  The uncertainty, fear, and waiting are very hard.  However, you will get through this.  I have found incredible strength, encouragement, and comfort from the wonderful people in this community.  Come here for information and to share your fears.  Sharing what we are going through seems to lighten the burden.  We are all here for you.  Please let us know how you make out! You'll be in my prayers today! Dukemom PS  Do you have some good CDs for the car ride over?  Three hours is a long drive, and you'll need some good distractions.

Posts.Content: May 6, 2008 09:10PM Dukemom2 wrote: Your surgeon will order and get all your films, studies and such and have them before you get there.  He will look at the areas of concern, and tell you his recommendations. Posts.Content: Jun 28, 2008 05:17AM Dukemom2 wrote: If you are on Central time, you are one hour ahead of me.  My son lives in Dallas, and he's on Central time.  I'm glad your appointment went well.  From what I've heard from others who live in Canada, things take a little longer with your medical system.  There was one woman who was told that she'd have to wait 4 weeks for her biopsy results.  She ended up getting them sooner; after waiting a couple of weeks, she started calling daily.  I'm very confident your surgeon would not have recommended a stereo if you weren't a good candidate.  Stereos are less invasive, and that's a good thing for you.  Besides, you surgeon could have just recommended a surgical excision, which he would do himself.  Look at it this way, he is a good enough surgeon that he doesn't need to drum up business for himself.  Some surgeons just go right for a surgical excision without considering the lesser invasive stereo.  A wire guided biopsy is the route I've gone, twice now.  The first time the wires were placed with mammogram; the second time I only needed one wire, and it was placed with ultrasound.  In both cases, you are given a local to numb the breast, so it isn't too painful.  It's not overly comfortable, but it's not bad.  Ativan or Xanax ahead of time, regardless, is an excellent idea! I learned from last time to have a very soft pillow for my arm to rest on in bed.  That helps me stay on the correct side, and keeps me from bumping my boob with my arm during the night.  (I also had a nice nap this afternoon.) I hope there is a cancellation and you can get your biopsy done earlier.  Regardless, please try to keep yourself busy and distracted.  Here's hoping the monkeys behave themselves and leave you alone.  If not, don't be afraid to take the Ativan as needed - that's what it's for.  If you have any questions, or want to talk, feel free to PM me. Dukemom

Posts.Content: Dukemom2 wrote: I had my triple excisional biopsy Monday, and got the path report today.  The surgeon's nurse called and told me there was no malignancy, but that the surgeon wanted to discuss the details of the report with me when I see him next Tuesday.  From the wisdom of everyone here, I knew enough to ask that she fax me a copy of my path report, so I could read it and be prepared with any questions for next week. Two of the areas biopsied were nice and boring, and included "patchy dense fibrosclerosis, cyst formations, apocrine metaplasia, small fibroadenoma, and fibroadenomatous change". The other area wasn't quite as boring.  The report on that piece of tissue (4.5 x 3.0 x 2.5 cm) included:  atypical ductal hyperplasia present less than 1 mm from the margin; fibrosclerosis, apocrine metaplasia and adednosis; focally tubular.  This tissue sample then said "See Comment".  The comment for that tissue sample was, "An immunostain for cytokeratin 5/6 was performed on the ductal hyperplastic lesion and is mainly negative." From my time reading these boards, I know that in a path report there are often more questions raised, even with benign results.  While I am thrilled and grateful that I have no malignancy, I do have a couple of questions for the surgeon next week. 1)  Do I need to be concerned that the ADH was found less than 1 mm from the margin? 2)  Do I need to be concerned that the immunostain (which I believe is used to differentiate ADH from DCIS) was "mainly negative"?  I'd feel better if I knew what percentage was negative and what percentage was positive. 3)  I'm going to inquire as to whether or not I should pursue genetic testing.  My maternal grandmother died of metastatic bc.  My mother has a first cousin who dies of metastatic breast cancer (diagnosed in her early 30s):  she had one type in one breast; 4 years later she was diagnosed with a different type in the other breast; she underwent genetic testing before she died of the disease - and was told that she did have the gene for bc.  (That is all the family knows of her illness; they are amazingly uninformed considering she tested positive for the gene.  They have, however, requested her medical records from where she was treated, and they will forward the records to me as soon as they get them.) Any and all thoughts and suggestions on other questions for my surgeon will be greatly appreciated. I want to thank you all for your kind thoughts and prayers.  I appreciate all the wisdom and experience everyone so willingly shares here.  As I said earlier, I am thrilled that I have no malignancy.  However, I don't know that I'll ever completely relax, especially given my family history.  I plan to stay around on the boards, to continue to learn what I can about this horrible disease, and to support others who have abnormalities and have to undergo further testing. Dukemom "You have to accept whatever comes, and the only important thing is that you meet it with the best you have to give." ~ Eleanor Roosevelt Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: May 8, 2008 09:08AM Dukemom2 wrote: Kat, I'm sorry you have gotten a staph infection.  I hope they caught it early, and that it gets resolved quickly.  Do you have a fever?  After 'sleeping on' the information in my path report, I'm going to ask my surgeon about sending my slides out for a second opinion.  I had a problem with this particular lab after my hysterectomy two years ago.  During the surgery, the doctor discovered a growth in my bladder.  He removed it and sent if off to this same lab.  When my internist read the pathology report, he sent me to a urologist.  The urologist took one look at the path report and said I needed a second opinion on the slides.  The lab had used two mutually exclusive terms to describe the growth.  The urologist told me that if one of the terms was correct, the other was very wrong.  He also said the protocol for follow-up care was different for the two terms. He sent my slides to Johns Hopkins, and the new report came back that it was something completely different.  Thankfully, it was still a benign growth, and it required no special follow-up, but I found it very disturbing that the local lab had gotten it so wrong. It's great that they are keeping such a close eye on you, with 6 month checks on both breasts for life.  I know you will go into each check up holding your breath, waiting to learn if they see anything suspicious.  I don't know if we will ever lose that fear, but it's important to be monitored closely so that any abnormalities can be found early. Be sure to take it extra easy while your body does double duty:  heal and fight the infection!!  Please keep us posted. Dukemom

Posts.Content: Jun 4, 2008 09:03AM Dukemom2 wrote: I had a breast MRI last week.  It wasn't bad at all.  The MRI machine was open at both ends.  You will lay face down on a table (mine was nicely padded and not at all uncomfortable), with your arms up over your head.  Your face will be through an opening, like that on a massage table.  Your boobs will hang through two openings.  The tech gave me ear plugs, which weren't enough to completely drown out the very loud noises of the machine, but it did dull the noise.  I was still able to hear her talk to me.  When you get on the table, make sure you get yourself into a comfortable position, as once the test starts you have to hold still.  As I said, the clanking and other noises of the MRI machine are loud, but not too bad.  I just zoned out, pictured myself on a nice warm beach with gentle waves , and it was over before I knew it. If your MRI is ordered with and without contrast (as most are), they will start an IV on you before you get on the table.  They will take one set of films, then they will add a contrast material through the IV, and take another set of films.  I had no sensation whatsoever of the contrast being added to the IV. The entire thing was over in about 45 for me. I had my MRI on Tuesday.  My doctors received the written report from the radiologist Friday morning.  When I got my copy of the report, I noted that the radiologist had signed off on the report at 8:30 PM Thursday, the previous night.  I had been told that reports are usually ready in 2-3 days, and that the doctors will normally have them in 3-5. I'm sorry that you have been diagnosed with DCIS.  The MRI will let them know if there any other areas of concern.  Hopefully, your MRI won't show any other problems, and you can get on with plotting your course of treatment.  Best of luck to you.  Please let us know how you are doing! Dukemom

Posts.Content: May 4, 2008 12:00PM Dukemom2 wrote: Misty, If I'm not too incoherent, I'll PM you Monday night and let you know how mine went.  I'm having 3 wires (for 3 separate excisional biopsies, all on the right breast).  They told me to take a Xanax before I come in (with a tiny sip of water).  I've been told I'll have a local for the wire placement.  My surgery is supposed to start around 10:15. I'll be home some time in the afternoon. As far as general anesthesia goes, the chances of an otherwise healthy person dying from anesthesia are next to nil.  I've had surgery several times, and apart from being sick to my stomach afterwards, I haven't had a problem.  (They have come up with much better drugs to deal with that now.)  The beauty of general anesthesia is that once they have your IV in, they usually give you something right away to help you relax.  By the time they get ready to wheel you into the OR, you really don't care what they are going to do.  They'll say something like, "have a good nap", and the next thing you know you are in the recovery room and it's all over.  (As a side note, I'm a retired RN - and I never saw or heard of a patient dying from the anesthesia.) I know it's not easy, but try to keep your mind off of it as much as possible.  Today, I'm doing lots of cleaning (and I hate to clean).  I also think I'll bake a batch of cookies from scratch.  It sounds like a good thing to do, and should keep me out of trouble for a while this afternoon. Feel free to PM me if you want.  We'll get through this together! Dukemom

Posts.Content: Jun 17, 2008 09:14AM Dukemom2 wrote: Donna, After I failed my diagnostic mammo, I had my first consultation with the surgeon.  The nurse took my vitals, and had me take off my shirt and bra and slip on a gown.  All of my mammo films were up on the light box on the wall.  I spent the 5 minutes before the surgeon came in with my right boob staring at me.  When the surgeon came in, he went over the written report from the radiologist with me, and then had me come over and look at my films up close while he pointed out the areas they were concerned with.  He then did a clinical breast exam.  After that, he discussed the various methods of doing a biopsy (fine needle, stereotactic core, and excisional).  He explained to me that he preferred to do either a stereotactic core or excisional biopsy, and he drew me a picture to explain why a stereo wouldn't work in my case (my breast is too small).  He wanted to be sure that I understood why an excisional biopsy was best for me, and to be sure that I was comfortable with it - which I was.  I am of the "when in doubt, take it out" school of thought.  After I got dressed, I saw his scheduling nurse.  She asked me if there were any dates coming up that she needed to work around.  She told me she had to coordinate the schedules of the surgeon, the OR and radiology (I had wires inserted pre-op to identify the areas for the surgeon), and that she would call me the following day with the date and time for my surgery - which she did. I have my next consultation with my surgeon this coming Monday, the 23rd, to discuss my MRI and ultrasounds.  After you have your consultation on the 27th, maybe we can compare notes! Last time around, I found that my anxiety level got higher after the actual date was set for my surgery.  The monkeys got much louder and more obnoxious too.  Don't hesitate to ask your doctor to phone in a script for you to help you through this.  It is a very difficult and stressful time.  Many of us need something to help us deal with the anxiety and quiet the monkeys.  Feel free to send me a PM if you have any other questions. Dukemom

Posts.Content: Apr 28, 2008 01:46PM - edited Apr 28, 2008 01:54PM by Dukemom2 This is from http://www.breastcancer.about.com/: BIRADS 4:  Suspicious abnormality; not characteristic of breast cancer, but reasonable probability of being malignant (3-94%), biopsy should be considered. Don't you love their narrow range of probability:  3-94%? Pass the Xanax! My BIRADS was a "4", and I'm having three excisional biopsies one week from today.  Hopefully I'll be able to report that my score of 4 ended up being benign!!  Dukemom FYI:  BIRADS 5:  Highly suspicious of malignancy; Lesion that has a high probability of being malignant (>= 95%); take appropriate action BIRADS 6:  Known Biopsy Proven Malignancy; Lesions known to be malignant that are being imaged prior to definitive treatment; assure that treatment is completed

Posts.Content: Jun 14, 2008 06:25PM Dukemom2 wrote: Donna, I'm not a very patient person.  If it has been more than one or two business days, I'd call the specialist's office and ask if they have been able to schedule you yet.  That isn't being pushy:  it's looking out for yourself, taking a little control,  and making sure you don't sit around waiting any longer than necessary. You should also start a notebook and get and keep copies of all your reports (mammograms, ultrasounds, pathology reports, etc.).  You can either get them from your doctor's office, or some of us have been known to go directly to the Medical Records Department at the hospital (when the doctor takes too long to give us the results).   It's a good idea to have a copy of everything yourself, to help you know where you are and to have things in writing.  Just listening to the results, even when they are perfectly benign, can be a little overwhelming.  It's nice to be able to re-read reports, and look up terms, and better understand what is going on.  Even if (WHEN!) everything comes back benign, you will have the records in case you ever have another issue. My diagnostic mammogram was BI-RAD 4.  In order to show the surgeon exactly where the microcalcifications were located, the radiologist inserted wires (after numbing the breast), using the mammogram machine to guide the wire placement.  He was pleased with himself when he was able to "get" two of the clusters with one wire - so I only needed two wires.  The pathology report on one piece of tissue came back with a lot of very impressive sounding words, but everything was benign (YEA!!).   The other piece of tissue had a focus of ADH, atypical ductal hyperplasia.  ADH isn't malignant, but it's considered pre-malignant and puts one at increased risk of developing breast cancer in either breast, not just the breast with the ADH.  Because of that increased risk, and because of some family history, my surgeon referred me to an oncologist.  The oncologist ordered an MRI, to be sure there wasn't anything else going on.  Besides showing 2 seromas at the surgical site (normal post-op accumulations of fluid), the MRI also showed an enhancement at the edge of the surgical site that was "suspicious for residual malignancy or carcinoma in situ".  The MRI also showed a mass in another spot in the same breast.  That led to an ultrasound, which confirmed the location of the mass, and that the mass was solid and not a cyst.  Now I am waiting for my surgeon to return from vacation.  I have an appointment with him on his first day back, June 23rd.   Sometimes the fun just keeps coming.   I pray that your results are clearly benign, with nothing questionable!!  That is the best kind of report. Even though my faith has been a constant throughout my life, this has been a life changing experience for me; it has changed the way I view many things. Many of us, even those who have never before had a problem with anxiety, find that we need something to help us as we go through this process.   There is nothing wrong with asking for a prescription - our doctors know how stressful a time this is.  I have found that Xanax helps to shush the monkeys.  There are other anti-anxiety meds that are equally effective.  I hope you can muzzle the monkeys long enough to get some sleep tonight.  If you are overtired, it only makes the anxiety and stress that much worse (and it seems to make the monkeys a bit louder too). I have to admit, I keep all my what-ifs to myself.  I don't share them with anyone.  I don't think anyone, other than the wonderful women here, would ever understand.  I found myself going through a lot of old files of papers and organizing things.  I also did a lot of shredding of old documents.  Some women have the cleanest homes in town, others employ some good old fashioned retail therapy.  Then there is always exercise to burn off some excess stress, meditation, deep breathing. . . You need to find what works best for you.  What works for one person won't help the next.  Please don't ask me to clean!!  Dukemom
Posts.Title: BIRAD kathy46 Donna1843

Posts.Content: Jun 14, 2008 07:54PM Dukemom2 wrote: Donna, Thank you for your prayers for me for the 23rd.  I am hoping he will just go back in and take out both the mass and the questionable area at the edge of the first lumpectomy.  I'd rather have something perfectly benign removed than leave in anything malignant.  I don't even mind if I'm left with a big old dent.  For me, the peace of mind of having it out will more than make up for any cosmetic problems that might I might be left with.  Everyone is different.  We each need to do what we feel is right for us and for our own body. Just remember that your specialist, whether a man or woman, still puts his or her pants on one leg at a time!  Also remember that not all surgeons have the best bedside manner.  Many do, and that is wonderful when that happens.  But some surgeons, while technically superb at what they do, can't always muster a warm and fuzzy relationship with patients.  I haven't found a way to stop the what ifs.  They still pop into my mind from time to time.  I try to pull up my intellectual side and put things in perspective.  I'm not always successful.  Sometimes those stupid monkeys distract me and my mind wanders off to one of those dark places I don't want to visit.  Although the drug info, your doctor, and your pharmacist will tell you otherwise, I've heard stories of women who have a glass of wine with a low dose anti-anxiety med.  It makes the monkeys shut up a little more quickly, and it makes it easier to sleep.    The key is only one glass of wine (and not a 20 oz glass), and a low dose of Xanax or whatever you are prescribed.  If you have never taken the med before, I'd recommend you take the med alone for the first day to see how if affects you.  Until you do get a script, I can also confirm that a glass of wine before bed (or a glass of chilled Baileys, yum!) will also help quiet the monkeys. Good luck! Dukemom

Posts.Content: Jun 14, 2008 02:39PM Dukemom2 wrote: Donna, Some women here refer to the problems sleeping at night as the chattering monkeys running around in our heads - the stupid critters seem to wake up and get very active and vocal just as we are trying to sleep.  It can be hard to shut them up; they certainly seem to have minds of their own. At least you have had the diagnostic films and an ultrasound.  Some women have to wait long periods of time between each step; you are a little ahead in that department. It is especially hard that this is your first mammogram, because the radiologist has nothing to compare it to.  Do you have an appointment to talk with a breast surgeon?  That will probably be your next step - to let him/her look at your films with you and decide how best to proceed.  My mammo showed 3 clusters of microcalcifications (radiologist recommended biopsies of all 3).  Unfortunately, the surgeon said that my breast is too small for a stereotactic biopsy.  He said that a stereo is a good option for a biopsy, as it is less invasive than an excisional biospy (surgery to remove the entire questionable tissue).  He said he'd hate to send me for a stereo, only to have them make several tries and then decide that they couldn't get the cannula in at the right angle to get to samples needed.  (Me too!!).  So, I had the excisional biopsies.  If you need more info on stereotactic biopsies: http://www.radiologyinfo.org/en/info.cfm?pg=breastbixr&bhcp=1 The not knowing what you are dealing with is very difficult, and can be when the chattering monkeys get the loudest.  For me, I need to learn what I can about my options, so that I am comfortable that I am making the best decision for me. Once you have made a decision as to how you want to proceed, whether it be waiting (which you don't sound like you are in favor of - few of us here are big fans of waiting), or having a stereo, or having an excisional - I think you will feel a little more in control.  You are allowed to feel like "poor me"!  You are allowed to feel any and all emotions.  Whatever you are feeling is normal.  No matter what your emotions, there are many here who have or do feel the exact same way.  You are never alone here.  (Although things are a little quieter here on the weekends.  While there is always someone who will come along, on the weekends it may take a little longer.) I'm sending calming and benign thoughts your way, along with a hug! Dukemom

Posts.Content: Jun 28, 2008 08:38AM Dukemom2 wrote: djh47, I'm sorry you had to come here.  I, too, failed my annual mammo, and was called back for a diagnostic.  I did not have an ultrasound, because what they saw on mine was clusters of microcalcifications, which are not visible on u/s.  When told I need biopsies, I made an appointment with a breast surgeon.  He discussed the various types of biopsies with me.  Before I could even tell him that I would prefer an excisional biopsy over a stereotactic, he explained to me that my breast is too small for a stereo biopsy.   It is your body, and if you will feel most comfortable with an excisional biopsy, then by all means ask your surgeon to do so.  As long as it isn't something that will be harmful to you, your surgeon should honor your wishes.  I have now had two sets of surgery, both excisionals, and I had general for both.  There is much to be said for an anesthesiologist sending you off to sleep, and then you wake up and it's all over.  This is very scary and unnerving.  Don't hesitate to ask your doctor to phone in a script for something to help you with the anxiety while you are dealing with this.  Even if you end up needing a biopsy, please remember that overall, 80% of breast biopsies are benign.  The odds are very much in your favor. Hang in there.  Warm hugs, Dukemom

Posts.Content: May 10, 2008 08:22PM Dukemom2 wrote: Shabby, My exisionals were just this past Monday, May 5th (3 areas of concern; 2 were located with one wire - so I had 2 pieces of tissue removed, each approximately 4 x 2 x 3 cm)  The only time I'm sore now is when I take my bra off to shower.  Otherwise, I am wearing a very firm and snug front zip athletic bra, so there is no movement of my breast.  I have also been able to take it easy this week, and I haven't lifted anything and I try not to use the arm on that side any more than necessary. If you have been wearing a snug bra 24/7, limiting your activity and haven't lifted anything, and you are still as sore as you were the first couple of days post-op, I'd call the surgeon and ask if that is normal for you.  Perhaps he/she did more 'fishing' around in there, and that is why you are still so sore.  It's also possible that you may have bled some into the sites.  In any case, I would call the surgeon for my own peace of mind.  He/she may have you wait until your appointment later next week, or may want you to come in on Monday and get it checked. I think it's very natural to have raised scars at this point in the healing.  If you have healed enough so the surgeon has said it is ok to put a cream or gel on the scar to help minimize its appearance ( Kelo-coat scar gel, Mederma or a similar product), that will help to reduce the scar and fade the color.  Be sure to have your surgeon's permission before you start to put anything like that on your incision. Good luck, and let us know what he/she says! Dukemom

Posts.Content: Jun 7, 2008 12:19PM Dukemom2 wrote: Category 4 meant the radiologist gave your report a BI-RAD score of 5.  The BI-RAD scale is as follows: This is from www.imaginis.com/breasthealth : BI-RAD 0:  Further imaging needing BI-RAD 1:  Negative BI-RAD 2:  Benign Finding BI-RAD 3:  Probably Benign Finding - Short Interval                   Follow Up Suggested BI-RAD 4:  Suspicious Abnormality - Biopsy should be                   Considered BI-RAD 5:  Highly Suggestive of Malignancy - Appropriate                   Action Should be Taken Don't panic over having a score of 4.  Many people with a BI-RAD of 4 end up with benign results.  It is the radiologist's way of telling the doctor that he recommends an area be biopsied.  Having a biopsy, and having a pathologist look at the tissue under a microscope, is the ONLY way to tell if something is benign or malignant.  You should have the biopsy.  The odds are very much in your favor that it will be benign.  Good luck, and we're right here for you while you wait.  Don't hesitate to ask any questions, or to just share your fears and anxieties.  We all understand what you are going through. Dukemom

Posts.Content: Apr 24, 2008 10:17PM Dukemom2 wrote: Butch: I'm sorry you, your mom, and your family are having to deal with this.  Is your mom depressed?  Sometimes a person who is very negative about everything is clinically depressed.  My mother and I finally figured out that my father had been depressed most of his adult life.  He was in his late 70s by the time he got help for it (he started taking antidepressants, against his will - but his physician, my mother and I out numbered him!), but what a difference it made in his outlook on life and his attitude toward his illness. Will your mom let you go with her to see her doctor?  That's what finally got my father the help he needed.  My mother and I needed to share our concerns about my father directly with his physician (all in front of my father; nothing was done behind his back).  People who are depressed often can't recognize it.  If your mother is depressed, she will need medication, especially with the added burden of having to fight breast cancer. I'm not sure what community programs might be available to help with this, but I'm sure some others will come along who could advise you better in that department. In the meantime, do what you can to educate yourself on breast cancer, so you will be able to help your mom make the upcoming decisions that she will be facing.  This website offers many free publications, which help explain what lies ahead.  Take advantage of them. Your mother is very fortunate to have you as her advocate.  Stay close to her, and do your best to help her through this.  If it turns out that she is clinically depressed, and she gets treatment for that, you may find that she is no longer a negative person.  You, your mom, and your family will be in my prayers.  Please keep checking back, and let us know how you are both doing. Posts.Content: May 28, 2008 08:44AM Dukemom2 wrote: Even after menopause, when your ovaries are no longer producing estrogen, you can develop ovarian cancer.  According to M.D. Anderson's Cancer Center: Age: The risk of ovarian cancer increases with age and occurs most often in women over the age of 50, with the highest risk in women over 60. M. D. Anderson goes on to say: Currently, there is no effective early detection method for ovarian cancer. It is usually diagnosed in advanced stages, and only about half of women survive longer than five years after diagnosis. Additionally, many women have no symptoms of ovarian cancer until the cancer is very advanced - but which time it can already have metastasized.  If it were me, I'd have my ovaries removed ASAP.  The surgery can be done laparoscopically, and it's just not worth of keeping your ovaries -especially since you know you carry the BRCA1 gene.

Posts.Content: Apr 7, 2008 01:01PM Dukemom2 wrote: Hi shells, From http://www.medicinenet.com/: "An excisional biopsy is a biopsy in which an entire lesion is removed.  An excisional biopsy is in contrast to an incisional biopsy, in which only a sample of tissue is cut into (incised) and removed." "A lumpectomy is the surgical removal of a small tumor (lump), which may or may not be benign (or malignant).  Lumpectomy has come to refer specifically to the removal of a lump from the breast." It sounds to me as if it's a matter of semantics.  I think an excisional breast biopsy is another term for a lumpectomy, because in both cases the entire lump or area of questionable tissue is removed. We all learn here as we go along.  Hang in there, and keep breathing. Casey

Posts.Content: Nov 20, 2008 08:33PM Dukemom2 wrote: BIRADS 0 simply means that additional imaging is needed.  The radiologist is saying that he/she can't fully evaluate the films (". . . elements in both breasts that could obscure a lesion. . . "), and is recommending a possible MRI.  Since you have a history of BC, it sounds like they just want to be sure that there is nothing that might be hidden from their view.  http://www.imaginis.com/breasthealth/acrbi.asp  Have you spoken with your oncologist or surgeon, to see what other imaging they might want?  If not, I suggest you pick up the phone and ask what you should do next.  I'm not much for sitting around and waiting for someone to call me!

Posts.Content: May 31, 2008 03:31PM Dukemom2 wrote: Stephanie, SO glad to hear you are home!  Don't stop taking the pain meds too soon.  If they leave you feeling funny, explain that to the doctor and ask if she can switch you to something else.  I know it's the weekend, but the surgeon (or whoever is covering for her) has an answering service.  If you call and leave the message with the phone number of your pharmacy, he/she should be willing to phone in something else for you. (If it's someone covering for your surgeon, he/she will probably phone in only enough of something to get you through until you can talk to your surgeon on Monday.) It's very important that you stay comfortable without feeling drugged or fuzzy headed.  Are you still using ice intermittently?  That will help with any swelling, and will also help make it feel a little better.  (Just don't put the ice directly on any skin, and stick to 20 minutes on/20 minutes off, or 20 minutes on every hour.) Take it very easy, get tons of rest, and let your family wait on you hand and foot.  Healing vibes are coming your way! Dukemom

Posts.Content: Oct 21, 2008 02:13AM Dukemom2 wrote: It could be nothing, but all breast lumps should be checked.  Unfortunately, no single screening method is fool proof.  Whether it's a mammogram, ultrasound, MRI, PET scan, etc, each method can miss finding lumps/areas of concern.  Especially with your having had breast cancer, your sister needs to be very vigilant. Please make sure she gets her MRI soon.  I know she is scared, but this is no time for her to bury her head in the sand.  Not having the MRI (or biopsy, if the radiologist feels one is needed) will not change the outcome.  If there is a problem, the sooner it is found and dealt with, the better. Prayers that the lumps are perfectly benign.  In the meantime, hold her hand if need be, and help her get to her MRI.  You are a great sister! Dukemom

Posts.Content: Jun 17, 2008 05:58PM Dukemom2 wrote: I had a call back and diagnostic mammo for calcifications too.  Before I left, they did tell me I would need several biopsies.  They had seen one cluster of microcalcifications on my screening, but when they did the diagnostic, they noticed two bonus clusters.  The radiology tech mentioned that I could schedule a stereotactic biopsy directly with them.  I took their brochure and thanked them, and then made an appointment with a breast surgeon.  I'm glad I did:  he said he prefers to do either a stereotactic biopsy or an excisional biopsy, but that my breast was too small to do a stereo.  He said he'd hate to have me go through multiple attempts to get the core samples only to be told they couldn't get the right area.  (Me too!!) It's normal to be nervous and to worry.  We all do, even though we try to talk ourselves down.  It will be ok.  Just mentally prepare yourself for the worst case tomorrow, that you are told you need a biopsy.  If so, ask your gyn or your internist to recommend a breast surgeon - if you don't already know of one.  Then, make an appointment.  He/she will look at your films, go over the radiologist's report with you, and tell you what he/she recommends as the best method of biopsy for you.  Please try not to get too far ahead of yourself.  Remember that overall, approximately 80% of breast biopsies are BENIGN.  It's good to know what you are dealing with, and it's good to be prepared for the next step of options/choices that you might face.  We all have a tendency to think worst case scenarios, and have our minds wander off to dark places they don't need to be.  Try to just deal with what is ahead of you now.  We're right here with you as you go through this. Feel free to PM me if you have any questions.  I'm sending good thoughts and hugs your way. Dukemom

Posts.Content: Oct 16, 2008 07:29PM Dukemom2 wrote: There is a new Genetic Information Nondiscrimination Act bill that has been signed into law, but the new rules for insurance companies don't go into effect until June of 2009: http://hr.blr.com/news.aspx?id=78371 The GINA bill states that, "Group and individual health insurers are prohibited from using genetic information to determine insurance eligibility. Increasing an insurance premium based on genetic information is also prohibited."  Just keep in mind that insurance companies are not required to comply with new law until June of next year. Talk to your doctor, and see if she is comfortable with you waiting until June to have the testing done.  If not, you can always talk to your insurance company and ask what their current policy is.  Not that I don't trust insurance companies, but if they tell you that a positive outcome of genetic testing won't affect your insurance coverage at all - I'd ask for that in writing. Good luck! Dukemom

Posts.Content: Jul 3, 2008 02:15PM Dukemom2 wrote: I was in your shoes yesterday.  I had 2 lumpectomies last Thursday; the surgeon told my husband he should have the results Friday and he would call.  I waited, and Monday and then Tuesday came and went.  I was thinking all the worst thoughts.  I called yesterday at 1 PM and left a message for the nurse, who was at lunch.  I called back before 5, when I hadn't heard from her.  She had gotten busy and hadn't had "time to call me".  She said she had to call over to Pathology to get the report.  When I had her fax me a copy, (both were BENIGN), I saw that the pathologist had signed off on the report last Friday.  I seriously want to hurt someone for sitting on that report for so many days. Prayers that you are only dealing with someone equally thoughtless and incompetent.  Keep calling and calling.  Please let us know as soon as you hear! Dukemom

Posts.Content: May 2, 2008 05:44PM Dukemom2 wrote: I'm very sorry you and your wife are dealing with this.  The chances of getting breast cancer in her 20s is very rare, but it can happen.  It is very likely that a lump at her age is either a fibroadenoma (benign) or a benign cyst.  I would recommend that she (or you) call her gyn Monday and make an appointment to have it checked out.  The gyn will likely order an ultrasound (they are easier to read on younger women than mammograms, because younger women have denser breast tissue).  You will both feel better having it checked out. Try not to be too anxious or frightened.  I know that it isn't easy, but try to stay distracted.  You are wonderful to be so helpful and supportive with your wife. Please check back here as often as you need.  Ask any questions, and feel free to vent.  We're all very good at listening, and we understand just what you are going through.  I'll be sending calming and benign thoughts your way!  (And please keep us posted!) Dukemom
